title: Photo ID required since 2014
content: Alabama requires photo ID to vote and closed 31 DMV offices in 2015, primarily in Black Belt counties with highest Black populations. After backlash, some part-time offices reopened.
source: Alabama Secretary of State; Brennan Center

title: ID law struck down, then reinstated
content: Arkansas's voter ID law was struck down by state courts in 2014, then reinstated via constitutional amendment in 2018. The state has no early voting and limited absentee access.
source: Arkansas Secretary of State; National Conference of State Legislatures

title: Felony disenfranchisement persists
content: Despite 2018's Amendment 4 restoring voting rights, Florida's legislature added fees requirement. Over 1.1 million Floridians with felony convictions remain disenfranchised, disproportionately Black.

title: Drop boxes cut 87%
content: SB 202 (2021) cut metro-Atlanta drop boxes from 107 in 2020 to just 16, with steepest losses in Fulton and DeKalb counties, the state's largest Black population centers.

title: No early voting expansion
content: Louisiana offers only 7 days of early voting (compared to 46 days in California). The state requires photo ID and has some of the most restrictive absentee voting rules in the nation.

title: Jim Crow-era provision survives
content: Mississippi still uses an 1890 provision requiring statewide candidates to win both the popular vote AND a majority of state House districts, designed explicitly to dilute Black voting power.

title: "Surgical precision" targeting
content: The 4th Circuit struck down NC's 2013 law, finding it targeted Black voters "with almost surgical precision." The legislature passed new restrictions (S747) in 2023.

title: First post-Shelby restriction blocked
content: SC was the first state to pass a voter ID law after Shelby County (2013). A previous version was blocked by DOJ under preclearance. Current law requires photo ID with narrow exceptions.
source: South Carolina Election Commission; DOJ records

title: Harshest registration penalties
content: Tennessee made it a felony to submit incomplete voter registration forms (2019), targeting voter registration drives. A federal court blocked parts of the law as unconstitutional.
source: Tennessee HB 1079; League of Women Voters v. Hargett

title: Mail ballot rejections spike
content: Under SB 1 (2021), over 12,000 mail ballots were rejected in the first election, disproportionately affecting Black and Latino voters in Harris County and other urban areas.

title: Turnout rises with access
content: After adding no-excuse absentee voting and same-day registration, Virginia's 2020 turnout jumped 9 points, the largest increase in the South. Virginia is now the only former Confederate state voting Democratic.
